title: St Kitts and Nevis profile - Timeline

content: - Christopher Columbus lands on the islands and names St Kitts after his patron saint, Christopher.
St Kitts, pictured in the 1920s, was a major producer of suger until 2005
- The British establish their first Caribbean colony on St Kitts.
- The British massacre 2,000 indigenous Caribs.
- The British establish a colony on Nevis.
- France relinquishes claims on St Kitts in the Treaty of Versailles.
- St Kitts, Nevis and Anguilla united as a British dependency.
- Centre-Left Labour Party founded to campaign for independence.
- St Kitts, Nevis and Anguilla become an internally self-governing member of the West Indies Associated States with Labour Party leader Robert Bradshaw as prime minister.
- Nevis Reformation Party founded, campaigns for independence.
- Anguilla placed under direct British rule following a rebellion against domination by St Kitts.
- Anguilla granted a constitution and its union with St Kitts and Nevis formally revoked.
- St Kitts and Nevis jointly attain independence within the British Commonwealth with Kennedy Simmonds as prime minister.
- Anti-government demonstrations take place following an inconclusive general election.
- A state of emergency is declared after anti-government riots by Labour Party supporters in the capital, Basseterre.

- Prime Minister Kennedy Simmonds loses in a general election which he had called following a scandal involving allegations of drug smuggling; Labour Party leader Denzil Douglas becomes prime minister.
- Nevis legislators authorise a referendum on the issue of whether the island should secede from St Kitts.
July - St Kitts and Nevis carries out its first execution in 17 years despite international protests.
August - Referendum on Nevis independence fails to achieve the two-thirds majority required for the island to secede.
September - Hurricane George strikes.
- Denzil Douglas begins a second term as prime minister after his Labour Party wins a majority of seats in a general election.
March - Largest hotel complex in the eastern Caribbean opens on Frigate Bay, St Kitts.
October - Denzil Douglas begins a third consecutive term as prime minister.
2005March - Government decides to close the 300-year-old, loss-making sugar industry after the
harvest.
December - First execution in over a decade when Charles Elroy Laplace was hanged for murder. Government said it hoped this would serve as a deterrent against high levels of violent crime.
January - Denzil Douglas wins a fourth consecutive term as premier.
May - Paris Club of creditor governments agrees to restructure St Kitts and Nevis' public debt, cutting interest payments by 90%.
May - The US Treasury warns that "illicit actors" are abusing a scheme offering fast-track St Kitts and Nevis citizenship in return for investing in the country.
February - The Team Unity coalition wins elections, ending the former ruling Saint Kitts and Nevis Labour Party's 20-year reign.
August - Terrance Drew elected as prime minister after his St Kitts and Nevis Labour Party wins the general election.
